title: Jack Dorsey
content:
{{Short description|American internet entrepreneur (born 1976)}}
{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}}
{{Infobox person
| name               = 
| image              = Jack Dorsey 2014 (cropped).jpg
| caption            = Dorsey in 2014
| birth_name         = Jack Patrick Dorsey
| birth_date         = {{birth date and age|1976|11|19}}
| birth_place        = [[St. Louis]], [[Missouri]], U.S.
| occupation         = {{hlist|Programmer|Internet entrepreneur}}
| known_for          = Co-founding [[Twitter, Inc.]] and [[Block, Inc.]]
| boards             = {{plainlist|
* Block, Inc.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://squareup.com/about#board|title=About Square|publisher=Square|access-date=January 31, 2017}}</ref>
* [[Berggruen Institute]]'s Governance Center<ref name="auto">{{cite magazine |url=http://www.townandcountrymag.com/society/money-and-power/a5994/nicolas-berggreun-interview/ |title=Why Nicolas Berggruen is Creating an Institute for Geniuses |magazine=[[Town & Country (magazine)|Town & Country]] |date=May 11, 2016 |quote=Another wing of the Berggruen Institute has technologists like Elon Musk and Twitter co-founder Jack Dorsey, as well as former treasury secretary Larry Summers |access-date=April 17, 2017 |first=Vicky |last=Ward }}</ref>
 }}
}}

'''Jack Patrick Dorsey''' (born November 19, 1976)<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.ajc.com/news/national/who-jack-dorsey-founder-twitter-square/a1Xbw34yAUSVRfjjMXZpdI/|title= Who is Jack Dorsey, co-founder of Twitter, Square?|work=The Atlanta Journal-Constitution|date=May 9, 2019}}</ref> is an American Internet entrepreneur, philanthropist, and programmer, who is a co-founder and former CEO of [[Twitter, Inc.]] from 2015 until 2021, as well as co-founder, principal executive officer and chairperson<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-04-20 |title=SEC 8-K Filing |url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1512673/000119312522115187/d337596d8k.htm |website=SEC.gov}}</ref> of [[Block, Inc.]], which is the developer of the [[Square (financial services)|Square]] financial services platform. As of October 2023, ''[[Forbes]]'' estimated his net worth to be $3.1 billion.<ref>{{Cite web |date=October 2023|title=Jack Dorsey |language=en |website=Forbes|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/jack-dorsey/?sh=6f0d9a8c2372 |access-date=9 October 2023}}</ref>

== Early life ==
Dorsey was born and raised in [[St. Louis]], Missouri.<ref>{{cite news|first=Tom|last=Leonard|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/twitter/4388880/Profile-Twitter-founders-Jack-Dorsey-Biz-Stone-and-Evan-Williams.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220111/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/twitter/4388880/Profile-Twitter-founders-Jack-Dorsey-Biz-Stone-and-Evan-Williams.html |archive-date=January 11, 2022 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live|title=Profile Twitter founders: Jack Dorsey, Biz Stone and Evan Williams |newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|date=29 January 2009|access-date=January 14, 2014}}{{cbignore}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Lisa|last=Brown|url=http://www.stltoday.com/business/article_d3a250de-56a1-5038-b114-45426cc8bf3a.html|title=Taste of St. Louis first major event to use Square|newspaper=[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]]|date=September 29, 2010 |access-date=January 14, 2014}}</ref> His father is Tim Dorsey and his mother is Marcia (née Smith) Dorsey.<ref name="Glaser">{{cite news |url=http://mediashift.org/2007/05/twitter-founders-thrive-on-micro-blogging-constraints137/|title=Twitter Founders Thrive on Micro-Blogging Constraints|last=Glaser|first=Mark|date=May 17, 2007|access-date=November 5, 2008|website=MediaShift}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.latercera.com/contenido/739_127714_9.shtml |title=Jack Dorsey, creador de twitter: 'En 140 caracteres la gente se siente más libre al escribir'|website=[[La Tercera]]|access-date=January 14, 2014|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141006101644/http://www.latercera.com/contenido/739_127714_9.shtml|archive-date=October 6, 2014|language=es |first=Andrew|last=Chernin}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=VP&p_theme=vp&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=12C3E28404FD9298&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |title=Twitter creator keeps it quiet and quirky |newspaper=St. Louis Post-Dispatch |via=The Virginian-Pilot |date=November 26, 2009 |page=A23 |access-date=January 14, 2014 |url-access=registration |first=Tim |last=Barker }}</ref> Jack Dorsey is partly of [[Italians|Italian]] descent on his mother's side.<ref>{{cite magazine|first=David|last=Kamp |date=June 10, 2013|url=http://www.vanityfair.com/culture/2013/07/jack-dorsey-diet-purple-foods|title=Jack Dorsey Believes That Eating Purple Food Makes You Healthier|magazine=[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]|access-date=January 14, 2014}}</ref> His father worked for a company that developed mass [[spectrometer]]s and his mother was a homemaker.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/youngest-billionaires-forbes-400-11-060000953.html |title=The youngest billionaires on the Forbes 400: 11 under 40 |work=[[Yahoo! Finance]] |date=September 30, 2014 |first=Natalie |last=Robehmed |access-date=October 1, 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141002021005/https://finance.yahoo.com/news/youngest-billionaires-forbes-400-11-060000953.html |archive-date=October 2, 2014 }}</ref> He was raised [[Catholic Church|Catholic]], and his uncle is a Catholic priest in Cincinnati.<ref name=native />

Dorsey attended [[Bishop DuBourg High School]]. In his younger days, he worked occasionally as a fashion model.<ref>{{cite tweet |number=375089278054711298 |first=Jack |last=Dorsey |user=jack |date=September 3, 2013 |title=Me in my (very) short-lived days as a vintage clothing model: flic.kr/p/hG5x5 }}</ref><ref>{{cite tweet |number=599292408044474369 |first=Jack |last=Dorsey |user=jack |date=May 15, 2015 |title=@ScottLucas86 @LizFiandaca @jeremys did it include my modeling days? m.flickr.com/#/photos/jackd… }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/jackdorsey/188883710/ |first=Jack |last=Dorsey |website=[[Flickr]] |date=July 13, 2006 |title=I read Gray's Anatomy }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/jackdorsey/188883635/ |first=Jack |last=Dorsey |website=Flickr |date=July 13, 2006 |title=Noele took pictures of me }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/jackdorsey/188883621/ |first=Jack |last=Dorsey |website=[[Flickr]]|date=July 13, 2006 |title=Who needs a nosering? }}</ref> By age 14, he had become interested in [[Dispatch (logistics)|dispatch routing]]. Dorsey enrolled at the [[Missouri University of Science and Technology|University of Missouri–Rolla]] in 1995 and attended for two-plus years<ref name="native">{{cite news |url=http://www.stltoday.com/news/native-son-sets-st-louis-atwitter-he-s-always-seen/article_635e1f22-b802-50d4-bc42-29a464ef72ad.html |title=Native son sets St. Louis atwitter |date=November 15, 2009 |access-date=January 17, 2018 |newspaper=[[St. Louis Post-Dispatch]] |first=Tim |last=Barker }}</ref> before transferring to [[New York University]] in 1997, but he dropped out two years later,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rampton|first1=John|title=12 of the most successful entrepreneurs who dropped out of college |url=http://mashable.com/2016/09/22/12-entrepreneurs-who-dropped-out-of-college/#sBYQqStW1aq6|access-date=January 16, 2018 |newspaper=Mashable |date=September 22, 2016}}</ref> one semester short of graduating.<ref name="native" /> He came up with the idea that eventually became [[Twitter]] while studying at New York University.<ref name="native" /><ref>{{cite news |url=https://techcrunch.com/2010/04/27/jack-dorsey-fred-wilson-twitter-book-excerpt/ |title=When Jack Dorsey Met Fred Wilson, And Other Twitter Tales (Book Excerpt) |first=Jeffrey |last=Bussgang |website=[[TechCrunch]] |date=April 27, 2010 |access-date=September 23, 2018 |quote=Jack ... moved to New York, transferred to NYU, and started writing dispatch software ... 'They're all reporting constantly where they are and what work they're doing ... I thought that abstraction was so cool that I wanted that same thing for my friends.' }}</ref>

While working on dispatching as a programmer, Dorsey moved to California.<ref name="BW">{{cite magazine|magazine=[[BusinessWeek]]|title=Tech's Next Gen: The Best and Brightest|url=http://images.businessweek.com/ss/07/03/0326_tech_entrepreneurs/source/10.htm|date=March 26, 2007|access-date=November 5, 2008|archive-date=July 11, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140711043659/http://images.businessweek.com/ss/07/03/0326_tech_entrepreneurs/source/10.htm|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name="dorseytweet">{{cite news|author=Dorsey, Jack|title=To be clear: I didn't attend Cornell (and didn't invent Twitter there). |url=https://twitter.com/jack/status/1480648277|date=April 8, 2009|work=Twitter|access-date=April 13, 2009}}</ref> In 2000, Dorsey started his company in [[Oakland, California|Oakland]] to dispatch couriers, taxis, and emergency services from the Web.<ref name=Dorsey>{{cite web |author=Dorsey, Jack|title=twttr sketch|url=https://www.flickr.com/photos/jackdorsey/182613360|date=March 24, 2006|work=Flickr|publisher=Yahoo! |access-date=November 7, 2008}}</ref> His other projects and ideas at this time included networks of medical devices and a "frictionless service market".<ref name=Dorsey /> In July 2000, building on dispatching<ref name=Glaser /> and inspired in part by [[LiveJournal]] and by [[AIM (software)|AOL Instant Messenger]], he had the idea for a Web-based realtime status/short message communication service.<ref name=Dorsey />

When he first saw implementations of [[instant messaging]], Dorsey wondered whether the software's user status output could be shared easily among friends.<ref name=Glaser /> He approached [[Odeo]], which at the time happened to be interested in [[text messaging]].<ref name=Glaser /> Dorsey and [[Biz Stone]] decided that SMS text suited the status-message idea, and built a prototype of Twitter in about two weeks.<ref name=Glaser /> The idea attracted many users at Odeo and investment from [[Evan Williams (Internet entrepreneur)|Evan Williams]],<ref name=Glaser /> a co-founder of that firm in 2005 who had left [[Google]] after selling [[Pyra Labs]] and [[Blogger (service)|Blogger]].

== Career ==
=== Twitter ===
{{Main|Twitter}}
[[File:Jack Dorsey-20080723.jpg|thumb|Dorsey in 2008]]
[[Noah Glass]], [[Evan Williams (Internet entrepreneur)|Evan Williams]], and [[Biz Stone]]  co-founded Odeo, later renamed Obvious Corporation, which then spun off Twitter, Inc. Dorsey became Twitter's [[Chief executive officer|Chief Executive Officer]] (CEO).<ref name="Glaser" /><ref>{{cite news |first=Patrick |last=Hoge |url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/print-edition/2011/12/23/executive-of-the-year-jack-dorsey.html |title=Executive of the Year: Jack Dorsey |newspaper=San Francisco Business Times |date=December 23, 2011 |access-date=April 30, 2017 }}</ref> As CEO, Dorsey saw the startup through two rounds of funding by venture capitalists.<ref>{{cite news|author=Miller, Claire Cain|title=Twitter Sidelines One Founder and Promotes Another|url=http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2008/10/16/ttwitter-sidelines-one-founder-and-promotes-another/#more-1642|date=October 16, 2008|newspaper=The New York Times|access-date=November 5, 2008}}</ref> He reportedly lost his position for leaving work early to enjoy other pursuits, such as [[yoga]] and [[fashion design]].<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://nymag.com/arts/all/approvalmatrix/approval-matrix-2013-10-21/|title=The Approval Matrix|magazine=[[New York (magazine)|New York magazine]]|department=Entertainment |date=October 21, 2013|access-date=April 30, 2017}}</ref>

As the service began to grow in popularity, Dorsey chose the improvement of uptime as top priority,<ref>{{cite news |last=Wagner |first=Mitch |date=June 24, 2008|title=Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey: Improved Uptime Is Top Priority|work=InformationWeek |url=https://www.informationweek.com/desktop/twitter-ceo-jack-dorsey-improved-uptime-is-top-priority/d/d-id/1068524|url-status=live|access-date=July 17, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200717110836/https://www.informationweek.com/desktop/twitter-ceo-jack-dorsey-improved-uptime-is-top-priority/d/d-id/1068524|archive-date=July 17, 2020}}</ref> even over creating revenue—which, as of 2008, Twitter was not designed to earn.<ref name="Wagner-2" /> Dorsey described the commercial use of Twitter and its API as two things that could lead to paid features.<ref name="Wagner-2" /> His three guiding principles, which he says the company shares, are simplicity, constraint, and craftsmanship.<ref name="Wagner-2">{{cite news|author=Wagner, Mitch|title=Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey Talks About Its Business Model |url=http://www.informationweek.com/blog/main/archives/2008/06/twitter_ceo_jac_2.html|date=June 24, 2008|work=InformationWeek |publisher=United Business Media|access-date=November 5, 2008 |archive-date=March 26, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120326120823/http://www.informationweek.com/blog/main/archives/2008/06/twitter_ceo_jac_2.html|url-status=dead}}</ref>

On October 16, 2008,<ref name="Miller">{{cite news|author=Miller, Claire Cain|title=Popularity or Income? Two Sites Fight It Out |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/10/21/technology/start-ups/21twitter.html|date=October 20, 2008|work=The New York Times|access-date=November 5, 2008}}</ref> Williams took over as CEO, while Dorsey became chairman of the board.<ref>{{cite news|author=McCarthy, Caroline|title=Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey steps down|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-13577_3-10068368-36.html|date=October 16, 2008|work=CNET News|publisher=CBS Interactive |access-date=November 5, 2008|archive-date=July 29, 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090729120453/http://news.cnet.com/8301-13577_3-10068368-36.html|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/online/daily/2011/03/jack-dorsey |title=Jack Dorsey Tells David Kirkpatrick How It Felt to Be Ousted from Twitter and Discusses His Big New Idea: Square |magazine=Vanity Fair |date=March 3, 2011 |access-date=April 30, 2017 }}</ref> During his time as chairman, Dorsey joined several State Department delegations, including a trip to Iraq in April 2009, led by [[Jared Cohen]].<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.wired.com/2009/07/ff-iraq/|title=Booting Up Baghdad: Tech Execs Take a Tour in Iraq|magazine=Wired|access-date=October 24, 2020|via=wired.com}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/twitter/5204148/Founder-of-Twitter-sent-to-save-Iraq.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220111/https://www.telegraph.co.uk/technology/twitter/5204148/Founder-of-Twitter-sent-to-save-Iraq.html |archive-date=January 11, 2022 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live|title=Founder of Twitter sent to save Iraq|website=The Telegraph|date=April 23, 2009 |access-date=October 24, 2020}}{{cbignore}}</ref><ref>{{Cite magazine |url=http://content.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1893244,00.html|first=Mark|last=Kukis|magazine=Time|title=Is Iraq Ready for Twitter? New Media in a War Zone|date=April 23, 2009|access-date=October 24, 2020|via=content.time.com}}</ref> In November, when Iranians took to the streets in the [[2009 Iranian presidential election protests|Green Revolution]], Twitter was scheduled to conduct maintenance of its site, which would entail temporarily shutting down Twitter's servers. Dorsey responded to a request from Cohen to delay the maintenance so that it would not affect the revolution in Iran, because Iranians were using Twitter to communicate and coordinate.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Keller |first1=Jared |title=Evaluating Iran's Twitter Revolution |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2010/06/evaluating-irans-twitter-revolution/58337/ |website=The Atlantic |access-date=May 25, 2020 |date=June 18, 2010}}</ref> Since President Obama had announced that there would be no meddling in Iran, the move sparked controversy.<ref>{{Cite news |first1=Mark |last1=Landler |first2=Brian |last2=Stelter |date=June 16, 2009 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/06/17/world/middleeast/17media.html |title=Washington Taps Into a Potent New Force in Diplomacy |newspaper=The New York Times |access-date=October 24, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite magazine|title=An American President Abroad|first=Ryan|last=Lizza |magazine=The New Yorker |url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2011/05/02/the-consequentialist|access-date=October 24, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.dissentmagazine.org/online_articles/will-the-revolution-be-tweeted|title=Will the Revolution be Tweeted?|access-date=October 24, 2020}}</ref> In February 2010, Dorsey was part of another State Department delegation, this time to Russia.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/02/24/world/europe/24russia.html|title=Washington Sends Delegation to Moscow, via Silicon Valley |first=Ellen|last=Barry|newspaper=The New York Times|date=February 23, 2010|access-date=October 24, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://fortune.com/2010/02/24/getting-punkd-in-russia/|title=Getting punk'd in Russia|website=Fortune|access-date=October 24, 2020}}</ref> On March 28, 2011, he returned to Twitter as executive chairman after [[Dick Costolo]] replaced Williams as CEO.<ref name="post">{{cite news |title=Jack Dorsey Officially Returns to Twitter|work=Mashable|date=March 28, 2011|url=http://mashable.com/2011/03/28/jack-dorsey-returns-to-twitter|access-date=April 30, 2017 }}</ref> On June 10, 2015, Costolo announced his resignation as CEO, effective July 1, 2015. Dorsey assumed the post of interim CEO upon Costolo's departure.<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Primack |first=Dan |date=June 11, 2015 |title=Twitter CEO Dick Costolo is Out, Jack Dorsey Back In |url=http://fortune.com/2015/06/11/twitter-ceo/ |access-date=April 30, 2017 |magazine=Fortune }}</ref> He was named permanent CEO on October 5, 2015.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/twitter-names-jack-dorsey-ceo-1444046580|title=Twitter Names Jack Dorsey CEO|last=Koh|first=Yoree|date=October 5, 2015|work=The Wall Street Journal|access-date=October 5, 2015|issn=0099-9660}}</ref>
[[File:Obama Tweeting.jpg|left|thumb|Dorsey and President [[Barack Obama]] at Twitter Town Hall in July 2011]]
In May 2016, Dorsey announced that Twitter would not count photos and links in the 140-character limit to free up more space for text. This was an attempt to entice new users, since the number of tweets per day had dropped from about 500 million in September 2013 and its peak of 661 million in August 2014 to about 300 million in January 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/twitter-changes-too-little-too-late-jack-dorsey-moral-authority-2016-5|title=Jack Dorsey is moving too slowly to save Twitter|website=Business Insider|access-date=May 17, 2016}}</ref>

On November 22, 2016, Dorsey was briefly suspended from his own Twitter account with 3.9 million followers. After restoring the account, Dorsey tweeted that the suspension was due to an "internal mistake".<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/twitter-ceo-jack-dorseys-account-briefly-suspended-1479871858?mod=e2twd|title=Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey's Account Briefly Suspended|first=Deepa|last=Seetherman |website=Wall Street Journal|date=November 22, 2016|access-date=November 23, 2016}}</ref>

In February 2017, Dorsey and Executive Chairman [[Omid Kordestani]] matched a $530,000 donation to the [[American Civil Liberties Union]] (ACLU) raised by Twitter staffers. Their match brought the total donation to $1.59 million.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Twitter staff donate $1.59M to the ACLU to fight Trump on immigration|last=Russell|first=Jon|website=[[TechCrunch]] |url=https://techcrunch.com/2017/02/01/twitter-aclu/ |access-date=April 11, 2017|date=February 1, 2017}}</ref>

In March 2018, Dorsey announced that an improved version of the [[identity verification service|verification system]] would be coming to Twitter. The purpose of redesigning verification was to let people verify more facts about themselves, emphasizing proof of identity.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2018/03/09/twitter-verification-all-users/|title=Twitter Wants to Open Verification to All Users|work=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]|access-date=March 9, 2018|language=en|first=Laignee|last=Barron|date=March 9, 2018}}</ref> The overhaul was not in place before the [[United States midterm election|U.S midterm election]] of [[2018 United States elections|2018]] to help in [[authentication|verifying the identities]] of the candidates.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2018/03/08/jack-dorsey-pledges-twitter-improve-blue-check-mark-verification-system/409310002/|title=Jack Dorsey pledges Twitter will improve blue check mark verification system|work=[[USA Today]] |access-date=March 9, 2018|language=en|first=Jessica|last=Guynn|date=March 8, 2018}}</ref>

In September 2018, Dorsey testified before the [[United States Senate Select Committee on Intelligence|Senate Intelligence Committee]] alongside [[Facebook]] [[Chief operating officer|COO]] [[Sheryl Sandberg]] about the use of social media by Russia and others to meddle in the [[2016 United States presidential election|2016 presidential election]]. Following this testimony, Twitter shares fell six percent.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/09/05/twitter-shares-drop-6percent-during-dorseys-senate-testimony.html|title=Twitter shares fall 6% as CEO Jack Dorsey testifies before Senate|last=Lucas|first=Amelia|date=September 5, 2018|work=CNBC|access-date=September 6, 2018}}</ref>

[[File:President Trump Meets with Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey (40715975903).jpg|thumb|President [[Donald Trump]] with Dorsey in the Oval Office of the White House on April 23, 2019]]
Dorsey met privately with U.S. President [[Donald Trump]] at the White House and discussed Trump's concerns that Twitter had [[shadow banning|limited or removed]] some of his Twitter followers, and those of conservatives. After the meeting, Dorsey tweeted that their discussion included making Twitter "healthier and more civil".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2019/04/23/trump-meets-with-twitter-ceo-jack-dorsey-white-house/ |title=Trump met with Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey – and complained about his follower count |date=April 23, 2019 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |first=Tony |last=Romm |access-date=April 27, 2019 }}</ref> A week earlier, Dorsey took part in a [[TED (conference)|TED talk]] about the social media platform's spread of abuse and misinformation, which has brought him criticism.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.businessinsider.com/jack-dorsey-twitter-abuse-ted-2019-4 |title=Jack Dorsey says Twitter makes it 'super easy' to harass and abuse others, and addressing the problem is his biggest worry |date=April 17, 2019 |magazine=[[Business Insider]] |first=Aria |last=Bendix |access-date=April 27, 2019 }}</ref>

On August 30, 2019, Dorsey's personal Twitter account was allegedly breached for nearly an hour by a group calling itself the Chuckling Squad, posting and retweeting numerous racist tweets.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/business/technology/article-twitter-ceo-jack-dorseys-account-hacked/ |title=Twitter CEO Jack Dorseys Account Hacked |date=August 30, 2019 |newspaper=[[The Globe and Mail]] |first=Eric |last=Thayer |access-date=August 30, 2019 |url-access=subscription }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-49532244|title=Twitter's Jack Dorsey has his own account hacked|last=Lee|first=Dave|date=August 31, 2019|work=[[BBC News]]|access-date=January 29, 2020|language=en-GB}}</ref>

On October 23, 2019, Twitter's stock price fell by nearly 21 percent, to $30.75.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://variety.com/2019/digital/news/twitter-misses-q3-2019-grows-daily-user-base-6-million-1203381789/#! |title=Twitter Stock Craters on Q3 Financial Miss From Ad-Tech Glitches, Daily User Base Grows by 6 Million |date=October 24, 2019 |magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |access-date=February 3, 2024}}</ref> The reason was an earnings miss off a third quarter report, which Twitter blamed on ad targeting problems. Dorsey had been making a concerted effort to dampen the effect that Twitter had on political elections, which entailed banning all political ads. This was also seen as a large contributor to the drop. Dorsey announced that, as of November 22, 2019, Twitter would ban all political advertising. The policy applies globally to all marketing campaigns about political issues.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2019/oct/30/twitter-ban-political-advertising-us-election|title=Twitter to ban all political advertising, raising pressure on Facebook|last=Wong|first=Julia Carrie|author-link=Julia Carrie Wong|date=October 30, 2019|work=[[The Guardian]] |access-date=January 29, 2020|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>

On February 29, 2020, it was announced<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-02-29/singer-s-elliott-is-said-to-seek-to-replace-twitter-ceo-dorsey|title=Twitter: CEO Jack Dorsey At Risk From Activist Investor – Bloomberg|website=[[Bloomberg News]]|date=February 29, 2020|access-date=March 12, 2020}}</ref> that activist hedge fund [[Elliott Management Corporation|Elliott Management]] led by billionaire [[Paul Singer (businessman)|Paul Singer]] was looking to oust Dorsey and nominate four directors to Twitter's board, including Elliott's senior portfolio manager Jesse Cohn.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.barrons.com/articles/twitter-gains-as-activist-investor-just-puts-floor-under-stock-51583167653 |title=Twitter Is Gaining Because an Activist Investor Just Put a Floor Under the Stock|last=English|first=Carleton |website=barrons.com|language=en-US|date=March 9, 2020|access-date=March 12, 2020}}</ref> The two parties reached an agreement days later, with Dorsey remaining CEO.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/interface/2020/3/10/21171477/jack-dorsey-elliott-silver-lake-deal-ceo-twitter-take-private |title=Jack Dorsey bought himself more time as Twitter CEO, but it might not matter|last=Newton|first=Casey|date=March 10, 2020 |website=[[The Verge]]|language=en|access-date=March 12, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.barrons.com/articles/jack-dorsey-stays-twitter-ceo-after-company-reaches-agreement-with-elliott-management-51583764869|title=Jack Dorsey Stays Twitter CEO After Company Reaches Agreement With Elliott Management |last=English|first=Carleton|website=barrons.com|language=en-US |date=March 9, 2020|access-date=March 12, 2020}}</ref>

In October 2020, Dorsey was one of several tech firm CEOs subpoenaed by the [[United States Senate Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation|US Senate Commerce Committee]]. [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] [[Roger Wicker]], who chaired the committee, led the charge to force the CEOs of Twitter, [[Facebook]] and [[Google]] to testify about the legal immunity the tech platforms receive under [[Section 230|Section 230 of the Communications Act]] of 1996.<ref>{{cite web|first=Lauren|last=Feiner |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/01/facebook-google-and-twitter-ceos-sub.html|title=Senate committee votes to subpoena CEOs of Facebook, Google and Twitter to testify|date=October 1, 2020|access-date=October 1, 2020|website=[[CNBC]]}}</ref>

He announced his immediate resignation as Twitter's CEO on November 29, 2021. Dorsey was replaced by the company's former CTO [[Parag Agrawal]], who took over as CEO. Dorsey continued to lead as the CEO of [[Block, Inc.]]<ref>{{Cite news |last1=Roumeliotis |first1=Greg |last2=Dang |first2=Sheila |date=2021-11-29 |title=Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey hands reins to technology chief Agrawal |language=en|work=[[Reuters]] |url=https://www.reuters.com/business/media-telecom/twitter-ceo-jack-dorsey-expected-step-down-cnbc-2021-11-29/|url-status=live|access-date=2021-11-30|archive-url=https://archive.today/20211130081013/https://www.reuters.com/business/media-telecom/twitter-ceo-jack-dorsey-expected-step-down-cnbc-2021-11-29/|archive-date=November 30, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |first=Lauren |last=Feiner |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2021/11/29/twitter-ceo-jack-dorsey-is-expected-to-step-down-sources-say.html|title=Twitter CTO Parag Agrawal replaced Jack Dorsey as CEO|date=November 29, 2021 |access-date=November 29, 2021|website=[[CNBC]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|author1=Jessica Bursztynsky |author2=Lauren Feiner|date=2021-11-29 |title=Twitter CTO Parag Agrawal will replace Jack Dorsey as CEO|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2021/11/29/twitter-ceo-jack-dorsey-is-expected-to-step-down-sources-say.html|access-date=2021-12-03|website=CNBC|language=en}}</ref> In May 2022, Dorsey left the board of directors of the social network.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.cnet.com/news/social-media/jack-dorsey-leaves-twitters-board-of-directors/|title=Jack Dorsey Leaves Twitter's Board of Directors|website=CNET|date=May 25, 2022 |first=Carrie|last=Mihalcik|access-date=May 26, 2022}}</ref>

In October 2022, Dorsey retained his 2.4% ownership of Twitter when the company was sold to [[Elon Musk]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/jack-dorsey-saves-elon-musk-1billion-rolling-over-twitter-shares-2022-10/ |title=Jack Dorsey just saved Elon Musk about $1 billion by rolling over his shares of Twitter into a stake in the new private company |date=October 31, 2022 |website=[[Business Insider]] |first=Kali |last=Hays |access-date=November 18, 2022 }}</ref>

=== Block ===
{{Main|Block, Inc.}}
[[File:Jack Dorsey in Washington D.C. - 2018 (MRW 4445) (44538272181) (cropped-2).jpg|thumb|Dorsey in 2018]]
Dorsey, along with co-founder [[Jim McKelvey]], developed a small business platform to accept debit and credit card payments on a mobile device called [[Square (financial services)|Square]], released in May 2010. The small, square-shaped device attaches to [[iPhone]], [[iPad]], [[iPod Touch]], or [[Android (operating system)|Android]] devices via the headphone jack, and as a mini card reader, allows a person to swipe their card, choose an amount to transfer to the recipient and then sign their name for confirmation. Square is also a system for sending paperless receipts via text message or email, and is available as a free app for iOS and Android OS.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://squareup.com/|title=Square|access-date=October 7, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2011/06/02/jack-dorsey-the-man-with-two-brains/|title=Jack Dorsey: The man with two brains|last=Hempel|first=Jessi|date=June 2, 2011|work=Fortune|access-date=March 12, 2018|language=en}}</ref> The company grew from 10 employees in December 2009<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.californiahomedesign.com/blog/2011/06/30/chd-office-space-square-san-franciscos-chronicle-building |title=CH+D Office Space: Square in San Francisco's Chronicle Building |publisher=California Home + Design |last=Pollock |first=Jennifer |date=June 30, 2011 |access-date=September 19, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130705145836/http://californiahomedesign.com/blog/2011/06/30/chd-office-space-square-san-franciscos-chronicle-building |archive-date=July 5, 2013 |url-status=dead }}</ref> to over 100 by June 2011. Square's office is on Market Street in [[San Francisco]].<ref>{{cite press release|url=https://squareup.com/news/releases/2013/square-opens-new-headquarters |title=Square opens new headquarters in San Francisco, announces plans for expanded offices in New York and Kitchener-Waterloo|date=October 7, 2013|publisher=Square, Inc.|access-date=March 29, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140413142657/https://squareup.com/news/releases/2013/square-opens-new-headquarters|archive-date=April 13, 2014 |url-status=dead}}</ref> In September 2012, ''[[Business Insider]]'' magazine valued Square Inc. at [[United States dollar|US$]]3.2 billion.<ref>{{cite web|author=Shontell, Alyssa|title=THE DIGITAL 100: The World's Most Valuable Private Tech Companies |url=http://www.businessinsider.com/2012-digital-100#7-square-32-billion-7|date=October 3, 2012|website= Business Insider|access-date=October 4, 2012}}</ref> Dorsey is CEO of Square, Inc.<ref name="Jack Dorsey Looks to Simplify Commerce With Square">{{cite web | url=http://www.wwd.com/business-news/technology/dorsey-looks-to-simplify-commerce-with-square-7365024?src=nl/mornReport/20140116 | title=Jack Dorsey Looks to Simplify Commerce With Square | publisher=WWD | date=January 16, 2014 | access-date=January 16, 2014 | author=Strugatz, Rachel}}</ref> On October 14, 2015, Square filed for an IPO to be listed on the [[New York Stock Exchange]].<ref>{{Cite news|title = Square Files for IPO as CEO Dorsey Juggles Twitter Revamp|url = https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-10-14/square-files-for-ipo-as-ceo-dorsey-juggles-twitter-revamp|website = Bloomberg.com|access-date = October 16, 2015|first = Alex Barinka alexbarinka Spencer|last = Soper| date=October 14, 2015 }}</ref> As of that date, Dorsey owned 24.4 percent of the company.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://fortune.com/2015/10/14/square-ownership-dorsey-ipo/ |magazine=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]] |date=October 14, 2015 |access-date=November 25, 2017 |first=Leena |last=Rao |title=Who owns what at Square }}</ref> In March 2020 the [[FDIC]] permitted Square to open a bank. It announced plans to launch Square Financial Services in 2021.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/donnafuscaldo/2020/03/18/square-gets-the-nod-to-operate-a-bank/ |title=Square Gets The Nod To Operate A Bank |date=March 18, 2020 |work=Forbes |first=Donna |last=Fuscaldo |access-date=June 21, 2020 }}</ref>

In May 2020, Dorsey announced that employees of Square would permanently become [[remote work]]ers.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/jackkelly/2020/05/19/after-announcing-twitters-permanent-work-from-home-policy-jack-dorsey-extends-same-courtesy-to-square-employees-this-could-change-the-way-people-work-where-they-live-and-how-much-theyll-be-paid/ |title=After Announcing Twitter's Permanent Remote-Work Policy, Jack Dorsey Extends Same Courtesy To Square Employees |work=[[Forbes]] |first=Jack |last=Kelly  |date=May 19, 2020 | url-access=limited}}</ref>

In 2020, for months, Square began withholding  up to 30 percent of the funds that merchants collected from customers using its [[Cash App]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://respectinvestment.com/news/square-jack-dorseys-pay-service-is-withholding-money-merchants-say-they-need |title=Square, Jack Dorsey's Pay Service, Is Withholding Money Merchants Say They Need |date=June 23, 2020 |website=Respect Investment |access-date=October 9, 2020 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210419215239/https://respectinvestment.com/news/square-jack-dorseys-pay-service-is-withholding-money-merchants-say-they-need/ |archive-date=April 19, 2021 }}</ref>

On December 1, 2021, CEO Jack Dorsey officially changed the name of the platform to Block, Inc. This was due in part to his interest in the [[blockchain]] as well as the new name encompassing the various businesses better than the current name, which is mostly associated with its merchant-payment services. The stock [[ticker symbol|ticker]] for Block, Inc. would remain "SQ".<ref>{{Cite news|last=Vigna|first=Paul|date=2021-12-01|title=Square Changes Name to Block, Days After CEO Jack Dorsey Leaves Twitter|language=en-US|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/square-changes-name-to-block-days-after-ceo-jack-dorsey-leaves-twitter-11638394200|access-date=2021-12-02 |issn=0099-9660}}</ref>

=== Bluesky ===
In February 2022, Dorsey joined the board of directors<ref name="bsky-board">{{Cite news |last=Dang |first=Sheila |date=2022-02-08 |title=Twitter-funded social media project Bluesky adds Jack Dorsey to board |language=en |work=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/technology/twitter-funded-social-media-project-bluesky-adds-jack-dorsey-board-2022-02-08/ |access-date=2023-04-30}}</ref> of [[Bluesky Social]], a [[Twitter]] [[Corporate spin-off|spin-off]] developing a [[Decentralized network protocol|decentralized social networking protocol]] and [[Web application|app]].<ref>{{Cite news |last=Barr |first=Kyle |date=2022-10-19 |title=The Folks Jack Dorsey Tapped to Make a 'Decentralized' Social Platform Now Have a Beta |language=en |work=Gizmodo |url=https://gizmodo.com/jack-dorsey-bluesky-twitter-social-media-1849676675 |access-date=2022-11-01}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |last=Dodds |first=Io |date=2022-10-31 |title=What is Bluesky, the potential Twitter alternative being tested by former CEO Jack Dorsey? |language=en |work=The Independent |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/tech/bluesky-twitter-elon-musk-rival-b2213967.html |access-date=2022-11-01}}</ref> On May 4, 2024, he announced he was no longer on the board, and on May 5, 2024, the company confirmed this.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Ha |first1=Anthony |title=Jack Dorsey says he's no longer on the Bluesky board |url=https://techcrunch.com/2024/05/05/jack-dorsey-says-hes-no-longer-on-the-bluesky-board/ |website=TechCrunch |access-date=5 May 2024 |date=5 May 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=MacDonald |first1=Cheyenne |title=Jack Dorsey says (on X) that he's not on the Bluesky board anymore |url=https://www.engadget.com/jack-dorsey-says-on-x-that-hes-not-on-the-bluesky-board-anymore-183902317.html |website=Engadget |access-date=5 May 2024 |date=5 May 2024}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Davis |first1=Wes |title=Bluesky confirms Jack Dorsey is no longer on its board |url=https://www.theverge.com/2024/5/5/24149543/jack-dorsey-gone-bluesky-board |website=The Verge |access-date=5 May 2024 |date=5 May 2024}}</ref> He instead endorsed [[X (social media platform)|X]], which he called "freedom technology".<ref>{{Cite web |last=Shapero |first=Julia |date=2024-05-06 |title=Jack Dorsey praises Twitter as 'freedom technology' as he leaves Bluesky board |url=https://thehill.com/policy/technology/4646630-jack-dorsey-praises-twitter-as-freedom-technology-as-he-leaves-bluesky-board/ |access-date=2024-05-07 |website=The Hill |language=en-US}}</ref> In a 2024 interview, Dorsey said that Bluesky's shift toward a traditional corporate structure and the introduction of centralized moderation tools were major factors behind his leaving the company.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Solana |first1=Mike |title=The End of Social Media: An Interview With Jack Dorsey |url=https://www.piratewires.com/p/interview-with-jack-dorsey-mike-solana |website=Pirate Wires |date=2024-05-09 |access-date=2024-05-09}}</ref>

=== Other projects ===
In 2013, Dorsey expressed his admiration of [[Michael Bloomberg]] to [[CNN]],<ref name="Tapper" /> and said he aspires to become [[mayor of New York City]].<ref name="Tapper">{{cite news|url=http://thelead.blogs.cnn.com/2013/03/21/jack-dorsey-on-his-desire-to-be-mayor-of-new-york-city-steve-jobs-and-being-a-bachelor/|date=March 21, 2013|author1=Tapper, Jake|author2=Pham, Sherisse|title=Jack Dorsey on his desire to be mayor of New York City, Steve Jobs, and being a bachelor|work=CNN|publisher=Turner Broadcasting|access-date=March 25, 2013}}</ref> He served as a judge for Bloomberg's [[NYC BigApps]] competition in 2011.<ref name="Foot 4">{{cite web|title=Mayor Bloomberg Announces Winners of NYC BigApps 2.0 Competition |publisher=NYC.gov|date=March 31, 2011 |url=http://www.nyc.gov/html/om/html/2011a/pr104-11.html |access-date=June 5, 2013}}</ref>

On December 24, 2013, Dorsey was announced as a new member of the board of directors of [[The Walt Disney Company]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Jack Dorsey Joins Disney's Board Of Directors|url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/12/23/jack-dorsey-joins-disney/?ncid=tcdaily|work=TechCrunch |publisher=AOL Inc|access-date=December 25, 2013|author=Anthony Ha|date=December 24, 2013}}</ref> In January 2018, it was reported that Dorsey would not seek reelection at Disney's March annual meeting, due to increased difficulty with conflicts of interest.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-01-13/facebook-s-sandberg-twitter-s-dorsey-to-depart-disney-board |title=Sheryl Sandberg, Jack Dorsey to Leave Disney's Board |date=January 12, 2018 |access-date=January 13, 2018 |publisher=Bloomberg |first=Christopher |last=Palmeri }}</ref>

Dorsey is a board member of the [[Berggruen Institute]]'s Governance Center.<ref name="auto"/> Dorsey gives advice in a chapter of [[Tim Ferriss]]' book ''[[Tools of Titans]]''.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://toolsoftitans.tools/titans.html |title=Tool Guide |website=Tools of Titans |access-date=February 11, 2021 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/01/19/jack-dorsey-says-the-best-investment-he-ever-made-cost-him-nothing.html |title=Jack Dorsey says the best investment he ever made cost him nothing |date=January 19, 2017 |work=CNBC |first=Kathleen |last=Elk |access-date=February 11, 2021 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2019/02/21/i-tried-twitter-ceo-jack-dorseys-morning-routine-for-a-week.html |title=I woke up at 5 am and walked 5.3 miles to work like Jack Dorsey for a week—and I'll never do it again |date=February 21, 2019 |work=CNBC |first=Kathleen |last=Elk |access-date=February 11, 2021 }}</ref>

Dorsey is a vocal [[Bitcoin]] advocate, and has spoken at Bitcoin conferences such as "The B Word". He has said that if he were not working on Twitter and Square, he would be working on Bitcoin.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2021/06/04/twitter-and-square-ceo-jack-dorsey-focused-on-bitcoin-btc.html |title=Jack Dorsey on bitcoin: 'I don't think there is anything more important in my lifetime to work on' |date=June 4, 2021 |work=CNBC |first=Taylor |last=Locke |access-date=December 17, 2021 }}</ref>

He also endorses and financially supported the development of the [[Nostr]] social networking protocol.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Torpey |first1=Kyle |title=Here's why Bitcoiners are flocking to Nostr, a social network supported by Jack Dorsey and Edward Snowden |url=https://fortune.com/crypto/2023/02/21/bitcoiners-flocking-to-nostr-social-network-jack-dorsey-edward-snowden/ |website=Fortune |date=21 February 2023 |access-date=22 February 2023}}</ref><ref>{{cite tweet |title=14 BTC deployed to @fiatjaf for #nostr |number=1603535971114487816 |user=jack |first=Jack |last=Dorsey |access-date=February 23, 2023 |date=December 16, 2022}}</ref>

== Personal life ==
In 2012, Dorsey moved to the [[Sea Cliff, San Francisco|Sea Cliff]] neighborhood of [[San Francisco]].<ref>{{cite news |title= We Hear Twitter Cofounder Jack Dorsey Now Lives In A $10 Million House |last=Thomas |first=Owen |work=Business Insider |date=June 18, 2012 |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/jack-dorsey-twitter-square-seacliff-house-2012-6 |access-date=August 15, 2018 }}</ref>

=== Meditation ===
In 2015, Dorsey said he began his mornings with meditation.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Twitter founder Jack Dorsey practices Vipassana in this Indian guru's ashram |url=https://www.businesstoday.in/latest/trends/story/the-late-indian-guru-whose-ashram-twitter-founder-jack-dorsey-goes-for-vipassana-239882-2019-11-25 |access-date=March 8, 2022 |work=Business Today |first=Melia |last=Robinson |date=January 3, 2018 }}</ref> In late 2017, Dorsey completed ten days of meditation known as [[Vipassanā]] taught by followers of [[S. N. Goenka]].<ref name=":0">{{cite news |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/twitter-ceo-jack-dorsey-does-vipassana-meditation-2018-1 |title=Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey tried the meditation craze that requires no sex, drugs, or talking for 10 days |work=Business Insider |date=January 3, 2018 |first=Melia |last=Robinson |access-date=December 27, 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey criticised for 'tone deaf' Myanmar tweets |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-46498876 |work=BBC News |date=December 9, 2018}}</ref> In November 2018, Dorsey went on a birthday Vipassanā meditation trip to [[Buddhism in Myanmar|Myanmar]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/12/13/twitter-ceo-jack-dorsey-spent-his-birthday-on-a-silent-meditation-trip.html |title=Why Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey practiced this 'extremely painful' ancient meditation technique for his birthday |date=December 13, 2018 |work=CNBC |first=Zameena |last=Mejia |access-date=December 10, 2020 }}</ref>

=== Politics ===
In 2019, Dorsey contributed financially to the campaigns of 2020 [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] presidential candidates [[Tulsi Gabbard]] and [[Andrew Yang]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Miller |first1=Katherine |title=Twitter's Jack Dorsey Donated $5,600 To Tulsi Gabbard |url=https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/katherinemiller/twitter-jack-dorsey-tulsi-gabbard-andrew-yang |website=BuzzFeed News |language=en |date=July 16, 2019 |access-date=February 14, 2020 }}</ref> In 2020, he donated $15 million to 29 mayors pursuing the piloting of [[guaranteed basic income]] programs in the United States.<ref>{{Cite magazine|title=Jack Dorsey Donates $15 Million to Mayors Testing Basic Income|url=https://www.ceotodaymagazine.com/2020/12/jack-dorsey-donates-15-million-to-mayors-testing-basic-income/|access-date=December 27, 2020|magazine=CEO Today|date=December 9, 2020}}</ref>

Until 2021, Dorsey applied "world leader" exceptions that enabled President [[Donald Trump]] to post content on Twitter that would normally be removed or generate sanctions per the platform's rules. In May 2020, some of Trump's tweets received warning labels, and from Election Day in November 2020, more flaggings were applied to his tweets.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.businessinsider.com/donald-trump-twitter-account-lose-world-leader-protections-exemption-20-2020-11 |title=Trump will lose his 'world leader' Twitter privileges on January 20, Jack Dorsey confirms — meaning he could get banned just like everyone else |date=November 18, 2020 |work=Business Insider |first=Isobel Asher |last=Hamilton |access-date=January 8, 2021 }}</ref> On January 6, 2021, after pro-Trump supporters [[2021 storming of the United States Capitol|stormed the U.S. Capitol]], Twitter applied a 12-hour timeout to Trump's account for violating its Civic Integrity policy. Trump's account was suspended permanently on January 8.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theverge.com/2021/1/8/22218753/twitter-bans-trump-permanently-realdonaldtrump |title=Twitter permanently bans Trump |date=January 8, 2021 |work=The Verge |first1=Jacob |last1=Kastrenakes |first2=Makena |last2=Kelly |access-date=January 8, 2021 }}</ref> On January 14, Dorsey defended banning Trump but also said it "sets a precedent I feel is dangerous".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-55657417|title=Twitter boss: Trump ban is 'right' but 'dangerous'|work=BBC News |first=James |last=Clayton|date=January 14, 2021|access-date=July 17, 2023}}</ref> On November 19, 2022, Twitter reinstated Trump's account following [[Elon Musk]]'s purchase of the platform.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.theverge.com/2022/11/19/23467280/donald-trump-twitter-back-elon-musk-poll |title=Elon Musk says he's letting Donald Trump back on Twitter |first1=James |last1=Vincent |first2=Sean |last2=Hollister |date=November 19, 2022 |access-date=November 21, 2022 |work=[[The Verge]] }}</ref>

On June 4, 2023, Dorsey endorsed [[Robert F. Kennedy Jr.]] in his campaign to become the Democratic party nominee in the [[2024 United States presidential election]].<ref>{{Cite magazine |date=2023-06-05 |title=Have Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and His Anti-vax Conspiracies Found a Home? |url=https://www.vanityfair.com/news/2023/06/robert-f-kennedy-jr-his-anti-vax-conspiracies-found-home-twitter |access-date=2023-07-04 |magazine=Vanity Fair|first=Caleb|last=Ecarma  |language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=O'Sullivan |first=Donie |date=2023-06-05 |title=Instagram lifts ban on anti-vaccine activist Robert F. Kennedy Jr. after launch of presidential bid {{!}} CNN Business |url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/06/05/tech/meta-rfk-anti-vax-instagram-hnk-intl/index.html |access-date=2023-07-04 |website=CNN |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=Jack Dorsey endorses fellow Bitcoin advocate Robert F. Kennedy, Jr. for president—and predicts he'll win |url=https://fortune.com/2023/06/04/jack-dorsey-endorses-bitcoin-advocate-robert-f-kennedy-jr-for-president-predicts-win/|date=2023-06-05 |access-date=2023-06-15 |website=Fortune|first=Steve|last=Mollman |language=en}}</ref>

== Philanthropic and other donations ==
In March 2016, Dorsey fully funded about 600 Missouri public school projects registered at [[DonorsChoose]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.stltoday.com/news/local/education/twitter-s-jack-dorsey-fulfills-wish-lists-of-hundreds-of/article_ae972260-d932-5c1f-8815-301cc9bb845d.html |title=Classroom wishes come true at hundreds of Missouri schools, thanks to Jack Dorsey |date=March 11, 2016 |newspaper=St. Louis Post-Dispatch |first=Elisa |last=Crouch |access-date=November 23, 2019 }}</ref>

In October 2019, Dorsey donated $350,000 to [[Team Trees|#TeamTrees]], a nonprofit started by YouTubers [[MrBeast]] and [[Mark Rober]], that pledged to plant 20 million trees by the end of 2019.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://teamtrees.org/|title=Help Us Plant 20 Million Trees – Join #TeamTrees|website=teamtrees.org |language=en|access-date=2019-10-30}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |title=The CEO of Twitter just planted 150,000 trees!!!!! AM I DREAMING?? :))))))pic.twitter.com/8CrSQlCvIr |last=MrBeast|date=2019-10-29|website=@MrBeastYT|language=en |url=https://twitter.com/MrBeastYT/status/1189348547889643520 |access-date=2019-10-30}}</ref>

On April 7, 2020, Dorsey announced that he would move about $1 billion of his equity in [[Square, Inc.]], just under a third of his total wealth, to Start Small, LLC, and to relief programs related to the coronavirus.<ref>{{cite tweet |url=https://twitter.com/jack/status/1247616214769086465 |title=I'm moving $1B of my Square equity (~28% of my wealth) to #startsmall LLC to fund global COVID-19 relief. After we disarm this pandemic, the focus will shift to girl's health and education, and UBI. It will operate transparently, all flows tracked here |user=Jack |number=1247616214769086465 |date=April 7, 2020 |first=Jack |last=Dorsey |access-date=April 7, 2020 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/hayleycuccinello/2020/04/15/jack-dorsey-bill-gates-and-at-least-75-other-billionaires-donating-to-pandemic-relief/|title=Jack Dorsey, Bill Gates And At Least 75 Other Billionaires Donating To Pandemic Relief|last=Cuccinello|first=Hayley C. |website=Forbes|language=en|access-date=2020-04-27}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |date=7 April 2020 |title=Jack Dorsey to donate $1 billion to fund COVID-19 relief and other charities |url=https://www.theverge.com/2020/4/7/21212766/jack-dorsey-coronavirus-covid-19-donate-relief-fund-square-twitter |access-date=14 April 2023 |website=The Verge}}</ref> He committed to funding [[COVID-19]] relief, girls' education and health, and [[universal basic income]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/04/07/technology/jack-dorsey-donate-1-billion-coronavirus.html |title=Jack Dorsey Vows to Donate $1 Billion to Fight the Coronavirus |date=April 7, 2020 |newspaper=The New York Times |first=Mike |last=Isaac |access-date=April 8, 2020 }}</ref> Dorsey has donated $24 million to over 40 different grantees for relief efforts.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Top 10 Highest Private Donations By Billionaires For COVID-19 Relief|url=http://www.forbesmiddleeast.com/billionaires/world-billionaires/top-10-highest-private-donations-by-billionaires-for-covid-19-relief|last=Gandhi|first=Jamila|date=May 12, 2020|website=Forbes Middle East|access-date=2020-05-17}}</ref>

In August 2020, Dorsey donated $10 million to [[Boston University]]'s Center for Antiracist Research, founded by [[Ibram X. Kendi]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.businessinsider.in/international/news/twitter-ceo-jack-dorsey-donates-10-million-to-ibram-x-kendis-center-on-antiracism-at-boston-university/articleshow/77665095.cms|title=Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey donates $10 million to Ibram X. Kendi's center on antiracism at Boston University|author=Ward, Marguerite|work=Business Insider|date=August 21, 2020|access-date=August 24, 2020}}</ref>

In May 2021, he donated $15 million to support relief efforts in [[COVID-19 pandemic in India#2021: Second wave|India's COVID-19 second wave]]. The three [[NGO]]s were [[Care International|Care]] ($10 million), [[Association for India's Development|Aid India]] ($2.5 million), and Sewa International ($2.5 million).<ref>{{Cite web|author=Sindhu Hariharan|date=May 12, 2021|title=Twitter CEO Jack Dorsey's aid to RSS-linked NGO sparks row {{!}} Chennai News – Times of India|url=https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/chennai/row-over-dorsey-aid-to-rss-linked-ngo/articleshow/82559722.cms|access-date=2021-05-16|website=The Times of India|language=en}}</ref>

== Awards and recognition ==
* In 2008, he was named to the ''[[MIT Technology Review]]'' [[TR35]] as one of the top 35 innovators in the world under the age of 35.<ref>{{cite news|title=TR35 Young Innovator|work=Technology Review|access-date=November 5, 2008|publisher=Massachusetts Institute of Technology |year=2008 |url=http://www.technologyreview.com/tr35/Profile.aspx?Cand=T&TRID=700|archive-date=July 2, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150702184104/http://www2.technologyreview.com/tr35/Profile.aspx?Cand=T&TRID=700|url-status=dead}}</ref>
* In 2012, ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' gave him the "Innovator of the Year Award" for technology.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://graphicsweb.wsj.com/documents/image_grid/?slug=WSJMAG112012#filter=.Technology|title=Innovator of the Year Awards|work=WSJ. Magazine |access-date=March 18, 2013|publisher=Dow Jones|year=2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130123172353/http://graphicsweb.wsj.com/documents/image_grid/?slug=WSJMAG112012#filter=.Technology|archive-date=January 23, 2013|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.college.columbia.edu/news/columbia-host-square-and-twitter-founder-jack-dorsey-september-16|title=Columbia to host Square and Twitter Founder Jack Dorsey on September 16|work=Columbia College|access-date=January 16, 2018}}</ref>
* At the 5th Annual Crunchies Awards in 2012, hosted by [[TechCrunch]], Dorsey was named Founder of the Year.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/01/31/founder-of-the-year-jack-dorsey-square-twitter/|title=Founder of the Year: Jack Dorsey (Square, Twitter) |work=TechCrunch|access-date=January 16, 2018|language=en}}</ref>
* In 2013, he was considered by ''[[Forbes]]'' the world's most eligible bachelor.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Durgy|first1=Edwin |title=The World's 12 Most Eligible Billionaire Bachelors |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/edwindurgy/2013/03/06/the-worlds-12-most-eligible-billionaire-bachelors/#9fbcf230de74|access-date=April 13, 2018|newspaper=Forbes|date=March 6, 2013}}</ref>
* Dorsey was ranked by [[Fox Business Network|Fox Business]] as the #4 Worst CEO of 2016, citing stagnant growth, falling stock prices, and his part-time commitment to Twitter.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.foxbusiness.com/markets/2016/12/21/worst-ceos-2016.html|title=The Worst CEOs of 2016|last=Tobak|first=Steve|date=December 21, 2016|work=Fox Business|access-date=January 16, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref>
* In 2017, ''24/7 Wall St.'' listed Dorsey among the 20 Worst CEOs in America.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://247wallst.com/special-report/2017/12/26/worst-ceos-in-america-2017/3/|title=20 Worst CEOs in America 2017|work=247wallst.com|access-date=January 16, 2018|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/business/under-armour-blog/bs-bz-plank-worst-ceo-list-20171228-story.html|title=Under Armour founder Kevin Plank lands on a 'Worst CEOs' list|last=Mirabella |first=Lorraine|work=The Baltimore Sun|access-date=January 16, 2018 |language=en-US|archive-date=January 17, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180117070202/http://www.baltimoresun.com/business/under-armour-blog/bs-bz-plank-worst-ceo-list-20171228-story.html|url-status=dead}}</ref>
